job_title: Property Management Officer in London, England
pros: The people are great to work with. When leaseholder's understand and appreciate your hard work, you feel very rewarded
cons: HUGELY disjointed from the top of the hierarchy at NHG to the front line staff. swapping CEOs and other execs won't solve the fact that PMOs have far too much to do on a daily basis. Don't man-mark, play zonal. NHG need teams dedicated to each part of the property management concept, i.e. 1 team for Arrears, 1 for Complaints, 1 for quick enquiries & 1 for more complex cases (those that aren't resolved within X amount of time)

review_title: Some good people but a classic example of chaotic make-work public funded companies frittering away money.
pros: This organisation has ALOT of money and if you can advance upward you will experience a good life on the expense account. The people are often well meaning and interesting people, trying to do their best, but sometimes they face an uphill battle given the system that they work within.
cons: Its just chaos and people doing their best against difficult odds. People mostly want to do a good job but, given how badly the organisation is run at the top, it can make that almost impossible. The higher up people go in the organisation the more political it gets.

pros: Wfh 2/3 days a week wfh depending on your line manager so flexible. Very diverse workforce. More Women than Men on balance. Free filter coffee on tap and squash.
cons: Ad hoc informal induction. Large company 2000 + employees so difficult to get to know colleagues. Split between 2 sites. HR not easy to ever meet up in person with or speak to . High volume of work and vulnerable tenants and stressful ASB cases, particularly. Hot desking between not only desks but floors 6 of them. Only alocated one tiny locker to keep personal stuff in. Very IT based, lots of odd, obsolete NHG databases you need to access for info. Little support. Felt very much on your own, it's a sink or swim mentality.

pros: - Company do offer holiday pay accruement.
cons:

- Company ask a lot of carers but offer minimal in return.

I wanted to leave after my first day.

pros:
- Good focus on health and well being of staff
- interesting work 
- if your face fits, you will do just fine!
- good benefits - upto 28 days holiday for staff, Simply Health plan, 
- can be busy at times, workload level is good. Peaks and troughs.
- lots of initiatives to address diversity/inclusion
- Most departments have a good work life balance 

My most recent manager and team are brilliant and I enjoy working them. My current manager encourages career development and looking for opportunities to raise each person's profile. Good range of different projects. 

My previous manager was the total opposite but lovely team members. Like any where else, just depends on your manager!

Career opportunities really depends on where you are in the organization.
cons:
- Organization is not to keen on flexible working. Although, if you want to have a 9 day fortnight or have a structured work pattern this is generally agreed by manages. Strong preference for working in the office (pre covid times) as opposed to home working. Covid forced them to look at this again. 

- Very hierarchical. Some directors will not respond to your email unless it has gone through your director. Lots and lots of directors! 

- Slow to get things done at times

- Transparency around appointments is generally unclear

- carrer opportunities great, if you fit in but that is just like everywhere else!

pros: Genesis like many other organisations has it's good bits and bad bits! Some the good bits are flexible working, friendly staff, diversity and purpose. It's a great place to start and build a career to move on.
cons: The bad bits are that the organisation is not yet where it needs to be but working hard to get there. There are some groups of staff that really need to leave as they are not right for the organisation they don't live the culture and make it difficult for those who do! Career development is non-existent as internal talent is not developed. Management don't trust people to do their jobs so over complicate simple things resulting in poor results. Lack of innovation to lead people to do things differently through role modelling.

review_title: I recommend this company to family and friends
pros: Great work-life balance. Ideal organization for women. Genesis regularly ranks in the top 50 employers for women. The company has emerged from a major re-structure and is finally able to focus on service improvement. Genesis knows where it is failing and it is successfully tackling these issues. The workplace culture is improving and I am happy with the opportunities to grow.
cons: There are some dinosaurs around who don't want to change their attitudes. This leads to internal politics and power struggles. Senior leaders need to work with mid management better. Poor communication within teams...people don't respond to emails or keep pushing ad hoc work away. Sometimes the work environment can be very relaxed and you will meet some people here with a complete lack of drive. usually these people have been around for 12 years or more in the same position. The L&D team needs to up their game.

job_title: Customer Service Adviser in Chelmsford, England
pros: The people who work in Chelmsford are fantastic and really care about doing a good job. Management are supportive and listen to you. People who don’t want to work hard or create negativity in the office are managed out - which is a good thing! Lots of opportunity to progress internally. It’s the people that work here and the culture that make this such a great place to work!
cons: Customers often complain about their housing officers not calling back and the repairs department are absolutely shocking! Repairs are what lets this company down. Lots of time spent trying to get other departments to do their jobs.

review_title: Notting Hill's motto is "Love where you work" (most of the time!)
pros:
Lots of internal job and development opportunities for progression.
Good warm friendly organisational culture, not to corporate.
Recruitment processes are quite thorough in getting right candidates for roles within the business.
cons:
management sometimes not as open about change which directly affects your job until the last possible moment.
Double standards sometimes from Senior management in HR department when dealing with and speaking about other managers within the business. 
Have moved to Kings Cross, London which is even further away from the roots of the company.

job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Camden Town, England
pros: Modern & stylish offices in the heart of London. Vibrant workforce with a healthy appetite for social events.
cons: Disconnect between management and staff, poor communication and lots of decisions being made by the board without a full understanding of how it affects the business process.

pros: Strong overall purpose; strong approach to employee engagement; flexible working; generous leave entitlements; support for colleagues; focus on improvement and change
cons: Overly reactive; too much still left to chance, too little focus on planning and managing the pace of change and improvement; expectations sometimes set at levels which are simply not possible, which may demotivate people; overly bureaucratic in leadership - 'collaborative leadership' ambition sometimes feels more like 'management by committee'

pros:
I have worked at Genesis for just over 7 years now and during that time have seen lots of change within the organization, I have to say these changes are for the better and Genesis is unrecognizable compared to the Genesis I first started in 7 years ago.  As an 'employee' I too have been through lots of changes of circumstances including; maternity, juggled the childcare of a young family and have also worked in 3 different job roles so I have experienced life as a 'Genesis employee' from a variety of perspectives.

The 3 main pros of working at Genesis are as below:

1) Career progression and opportunities:   For those who work hard, get involved in extra projects/forums and go the 'extra mile' within their roles there are lots of opportunities for career progression both sideways into a different team or upwards into a more senior role.   This has been the main reason I have stayed here for so long rather than looking externally for new opportunities.  I feel like I have really invested in Genesis and its residents in the long-term. Its such a big organization with a wide variety of teams so there really are lots of opportunities to keep learning for those who genuinely want to learn. 

2) Agile working practices, working from different locations flexibly, hot desking- This might not be for everyone, but I personally love the freedom of being able to move around depending on the needs of the job. Some days I'm in head office or if out of office and in-between meetings I can work in a coffee shop or library.  There is a big focus at Genesis (at least within my team) on outputs rather than being visibly stuck to the same desk 9-5pm which isn't necessarily efficient. I also find this helps my general wellbeing and maintaining a good work- life balance. 

3) Great staff: Staff at Genesis on the whole are friendly and helpful. My team colleagues are amazing and so is my manager which makes it easy to get on with the job at hand rather than using energy dealing with internal politics. 
Of course, as with any large organization there are some areas of the business where I think job satisfaction is low and this affects how they interact with other internal staff but on the whole the majority of people are helpful and really nice at Genesis.
cons:
1) Few accredited training opportunities- This may very well soon change with the introduction of the apprenticeship levy but currently there is nothing in terms of accredited training opportunities internally or externally. 

2) Lots of restructures, mergers and changes causes staff to feel anxious- The restructures itself aren't the problem as I like change I think it keeps things fresh, however for many staff  the constant change is disruptive and causes people to feel anxious.  As a result the run up to the restructure/change date  can be quite a difficult period of time to work in.

pros: It’s a job  if you can stand working with poor management
cons:
In my opinion and in the minority’s opinion it is a racist company that does not like white people. 
 All the pictures that you see online are fake as I never saw a clean and nice property all of the properties I was working on what I would run down smothered in damp and mould but we was still told to spend less.

The organisation invests in technology and isn't afraid of being the first in the sector to do something new.
cons: The senior team are quite "senior". The organisation can be very hierarchical and politics can stifle creativity and cultural change.

Infrastructure changes which affect employers salaries to a considerable decrease in wages.

Corporate bullying staff in order to make unrealistic deadlines and extended work hours including weekends and evenings which compromise the work,life,balance of a employer on pittance wages and they avoid operating in a legal compliance way and are profit driven company who exceed a property portfolio of Billions and have groups like investors in people investing in them and have shareholders and they emerged by subsidary groups like pathmeads housing and Sunderland housing and Paddington church housing etc they expect there staff to take a Job on decreased wage cuts of ten thousand plus in a annual salary and refuse redundancy unless they fail the interview and one guy was coached by a forum rep how to fail his interview in order to get his redundancy because he had been working there twenty years and they were demanding him to take a another Job role for ten thousand less and he wanted his redundancy but had to oblige the company policy Of Genesis management and to go through the reapply for his Job and fail the interview to get his redundancy..

pros: Nice people and a modern environment! People in senior positions work alongside those in junior positions and therefore, good relationships can be formed at across all job levels. Organisation also offers working from home arrangements.
